page.title: 01VILLAGE AT FOOT OF THE WOLDS
page.content: Brigsley, a village laying at the foot of the Lincolnshire Wolds with a population of some 293. Mostly agricultural in land layout, but few of the inhabitants earn their living from the land. Most are employed in industry on the South Bank of the Humber or in the commerce of Grimsby or Cleethorpes. Brigsley could be termed a commuter village. The houses are a mixture ranging from a 16th century thatched cottage to renovated farm dwellings to modern suburban type houses, some mock period. Amenities are few, a typical village food shop and a not so typical ladies dress shop and a family run garage. The only centre of entertainment is a village hall used by the Youth Club and by the elderly once a month. The spiritual needs of the villagers are in the care of a mostly Norman Church.
